chunks.Title: Introduction to Signals and Systems
chunks.Text: Welcome to the first lecture in the lecture series of signals and systems.

chunks.Title: Introduction to Signals and Systems
chunks.Text: In this lecture I will introduce signals and systems.

chunks.Title: Introduction to Signals and Systems
chunks.Text: But first we will discuss the syllabus.

chunks.Title: Introduction to Signals and Systems
chunks.Text: The syllabus is broadly classified into 10 different parts.

chunks.Title: Introduction to Signals and Systems
chunks.Text: The first one is the introductional part in which we have to deal with few basic definitions

chunks.Title: Introduction to Signals and Systems
chunks.Text: and classification of signals and systems.

chunks.Title: Introduction to Signals and Systems
chunks.Text: The second part is the basic operations on signals.

chunks.Title: Introduction to Signals and Systems
chunks.Text: In this part we will perform basic operations like scaling, shifting, integration, differentiation

chunks.Title: Introduction to Signals and Systems
chunks.Text: etc.

chunks.Title: Introduction to Signals and Systems
chunks.Text: In the third part we need to learn the basic system properties like static, dynamic, causal,

chunks.Title: Introduction to Signals and Systems
chunks.Text: non-causal etc.

chunks.Title: Introduction to Signals and Systems
chunks.Text: The fourth part is the time domain analysis of continuous and discrete time systems.

chunks.Title: Introduction to Signals and Systems
chunks.Text: The 5th part is the Fourier series analysis of continuous time signals and discrete time

chunks.Title: Introduction to Signals and Systems
chunks.Text: signals.

chunks.Title: Introduction to Signals and Systems
chunks.Text: CTS stands for continuous time signals and DTS stands for discrete time signals.

chunks.Title: Introduction to Signals and Systems
chunks.Text: The 6th part is the Fourier Transform Analysis of Continuous Time Signals and Discrete Time

chunks.Title: Introduction to Signals and Systems
chunks.Text: Signals.

chunks.Title: Introduction to Signals and Systems
chunks.Text: The seventh part is the Laplace transform.

chunks.Title: Introduction to Signals and Systems
chunks.Text: The eighth part is the Z-transform or Z-transform.

chunks.Title: Introduction to Signals and Systems
chunks.Text: The ninth part is the sampling theorem.

chunks.Title: Introduction to Signals and Systems
chunks.Text: And the last part is the random signals and systems.

chunks.Title: Introduction to Signals and Systems
chunks.Text: So this is the syllabus and we will try to complete this syllabus in the coming presentations.

chunks.Title: Introduction to Signals and Systems
chunks.Text: In this lecture we will start with definition of signal.

chunks.Title: Introduction to Signals and Systems
chunks.Text: So what is a signal?

chunks.Title: Introduction to Signals and Systems
chunks.Text: A signal is a dependent variable or we can say function of one or more independent variables.

chunks.Title: Introduction to Signals and Systems
chunks.Text: So signal is a function or dependent variable which depends on one or more independent variables.

chunks.Title: Introduction to Signals and Systems
chunks.Text: And let's say x1, x2 all the way to xn are the independent variables.

chunks.Title: Introduction to Signals and Systems
chunks.Text: So function f is a signal which depends on x1 to xn because they are the independent

chunks.Title: Introduction to Signals and Systems
chunks.Text: variables.

chunks.Title: Introduction to Signals and Systems
chunks.Text: Now we will talk about difference between signal and DC value.

chunks.Title: Introduction to Signals and Systems
chunks.Text: Any quantity is said to be a signal if it is varying with independent variable.

chunks.Title: Introduction to Signals and Systems
chunks.Text: And anything which is constant is not a signal.

chunks.Title: Introduction to Signals and Systems
chunks.Text: For example, the alternating current is a signal because the current is changing with

chunks.Title: Introduction to Signals and Systems
chunks.Text: change in time.

chunks.Title: Introduction to Signals and Systems
chunks.Text: The current is alternating with change in time in case of alternating current.

chunks.Title: Introduction to Signals and Systems
chunks.Text: So it is a signal.

chunks.Title: Introduction to Signals and Systems
chunks.Text: And if we talk about the direct current, it is not a signal because the current is constant.

chunks.Title: Introduction to Signals and Systems
chunks.Text: It is not changing with change in time.

chunks.Title: Introduction to Signals and Systems
chunks.Text: So it is not a signal.

chunks.Title: Introduction to Signals and Systems
chunks.Text: We are not getting any kind of signal.

chunks.Title: Introduction to Signals and Systems
chunks.Text: We are not getting any kind of indication in case of direct current because the current

chunks.Title: Introduction to Signals and Systems
chunks.Text: is constant.

chunks.Title: Introduction to Signals and Systems
chunks.Text: So this is the difference between signal and the quantities which are not a signal.

chunks.Title: Introduction to Signals and Systems
chunks.Text: Now we will move to the next part of this lecture in which we will talk about two different

chunks.Title: Introduction to Signals and Systems
chunks.Text: types of signals.

chunks.Title: Introduction to Signals and Systems
chunks.Text: The first one is the single variable signal.

chunks.Title: Introduction to Signals and Systems
chunks.Text: And the second one is the multivariable, multivariable signal.

chunks.Title: Introduction to Signals and Systems
chunks.Text: And as the name suggests, single variable signal is the signal which only depends on

chunks.Title: Introduction to Signals and Systems
chunks.Text: one variable or we can say the function of only one variable.

chunks.Title: Introduction to Signals and Systems
chunks.Text: And the multivariable signal is the signal which depends on more than one variable.

chunks.Title: Introduction to Signals and Systems
chunks.Text: In this course, we have to deal with single variable signals only.

chunks.Title: Introduction to Signals and Systems
chunks.Text: So we will focus on single variable signal.

chunks.Title: Introduction to Signals and Systems
chunks.Text: And the example is like fx or gt.

chunks.Title: Introduction to Signals and Systems
chunks.Text: These are the examples of single variable signal.

chunks.Title: Introduction to Signals and Systems
chunks.Text: The examples of multivariable signals are f1, x1, x2 and g1, t1, t2, t3.

chunks.Title: Introduction to Signals and Systems
chunks.Text: This function depends on two variables x1 and x2 and this function here depends on three

chunks.Title: Introduction to Signals and Systems
chunks.Text: variables t1, t2 and t3 whereas function f depends on x only and this function also depends

chunks.Title: Introduction to Signals and Systems
chunks.Text: only on one variable which is time t.

chunks.Title: Introduction to Signals and Systems
chunks.Text: So this is all you need to know about the signals, the definition of signal, what is

chunks.Title: Introduction to Signals and Systems
chunks.Text: the difference between signal and DC values and the classification of the signal based

chunks.Title: Introduction to Signals and Systems
chunks.Text: on number of variables.

chunks.Title: Introduction to Signals and Systems
chunks.Text: Now I will explain what do we mean by a system.

chunks.Title: Introduction to Signals and Systems
chunks.Text: The meaningful interconnection of physical devices and components is called as system.

chunks.Title: Introduction to Signals and Systems
chunks.Text: I will repeat the definition again.

chunks.Title: Introduction to Signals and Systems
chunks.Text: The meaningful interconnection of physical devices and components is called as system.

chunks.Title: Introduction to Signals and Systems
chunks.Text: System alone cannot achieve anything.

chunks.Title: Introduction to Signals and Systems
chunks.Text: Let's represent the system by this rectangular box.

chunks.Title: Introduction to Signals and Systems
chunks.Text: This is the system and if we have a system alone it cannot achieve anything.

chunks.Title: Introduction to Signals and Systems
chunks.Text: For example let's say we want to fill the overhead tank with water using a pump.

chunks.Title: Introduction to Signals and Systems
chunks.Text: So pump is a system but alone it will not be able to complete the task.

chunks.Title: Introduction to Signals and Systems
chunks.Text: So the system which is the pump must be linked to a signal.

chunks.Title: Introduction to Signals and Systems
chunks.Text: The system must be linked to a signal and in this case signal is electricity.

chunks.Title: Introduction to Signals and Systems
chunks.Text: We need to provide the electricity to this pump so that it can pump the water to the

chunks.Title: Introduction to Signals and Systems
chunks.Text: overhead tank.

chunks.Title: Introduction to Signals and Systems
chunks.Text: After receiving the signal the system must process the signal and produce another signal

chunks.Title: Introduction to Signals and Systems
chunks.Text: which is more desirable than the input signal.

chunks.Title: Introduction to Signals and Systems
chunks.Text: So this signal here is the input signal and after receiving the input signal the system

chunks.Title: Introduction to Signals and Systems
chunks.Text: must process this input signal to produce another signal.

chunks.Title: Introduction to Signals and Systems
chunks.Text: The output of the system is another signal and we will call this signal the output signal.

chunks.Title: Introduction to Signals and Systems
chunks.Text: So this output signal is more desirable as compared to the input signal and this pump

chunks.Title: Introduction to Signals and Systems
chunks.Text: is producing the output signal which is the mechanical work.

chunks.Title: Introduction to Signals and Systems
chunks.Text: To pump this water here to this overhead tank we need mechanical work.

chunks.Title: Introduction to Signals and Systems
chunks.Text: So this signal is much desirable as compared to electricity.

chunks.Title: Introduction to Signals and Systems
chunks.Text: The electricity cannot pump this water to this tank.

chunks.Title: Introduction to Signals and Systems
chunks.Text: We need mechanical work.

chunks.Title: Introduction to Signals and Systems
chunks.Text: So the pump receives the electricity which is the input signal and after processing it

chunks.Title: Introduction to Signals and Systems
chunks.Text: produces mechanical work which is the output signal and using the mechanical work we can

chunks.Title: Introduction to Signals and Systems
chunks.Text: fill the overhead tank.

chunks.Title: Introduction to Signals and Systems
chunks.Text: I want to make one thing very clear.

chunks.Title: Introduction to Signals and Systems
chunks.Text: Electricity is not always less desirable than the mechanical work.

chunks.Title: Introduction to Signals and Systems
chunks.Text: In this scenario when we want to pump the water to the overhead tank the mechanical

chunks.Title: Introduction to Signals and Systems
chunks.Text: work is more desirable as compared to the electricity but in other cases electricity

chunks.Title: Introduction to Signals and Systems
chunks.Text: may be more desirable as compared to the mechanical work.

chunks.Title: Introduction to Signals and Systems
chunks.Text: So the input signal and the output signal purely depends on the task we want to achieve.

chunks.Title: Introduction to Signals and Systems
chunks.Text: The output signal also depends on the same variables.

chunks.Title: Introduction to Signals and Systems
chunks.Text: For example if the input signal is the function f and it depends on x1, x2 then the output

chunks.Title: Introduction to Signals and Systems
chunks.Text: signal and let's say the output signal is the function g it also depends on the same

chunks.Title: Introduction to Signals and Systems
chunks.Text: variables x1 and x2.

chunks.Title: Introduction to Signals and Systems
chunks.Text: There are two types of problems we have to deal with.

chunks.Title: Introduction to Signals and Systems
chunks.Text: The first one is the analysis problem.

chunks.Title: Introduction to Signals and Systems
chunks.Text: The second one is the synthesis problem.

chunks.Title: Introduction to Signals and Systems
chunks.Text: In case of analysis problem we have the input signal.

chunks.Title: Introduction to Signals and Systems
chunks.Text: The input signal is there.

chunks.Title: Introduction to Signals and Systems
chunks.Text: We have the system.

chunks.Title: Introduction to Signals and Systems
chunks.Text: The system is there and we have to find out the output signal.

chunks.Title: Introduction to Signals and Systems
chunks.Text: In other words we can say we have the system, we have the input signal and we need to find

chunks.Title: Introduction to Signals and Systems
chunks.Text: out the response of the system.

chunks.Title: Introduction to Signals and Systems
chunks.Text: This type of problems are most general type and there is always a solution of this type

chunks.Title: Introduction to Signals and Systems
chunks.Text: of problem.

chunks.Title: Introduction to Signals and Systems
chunks.Text: On the other hand in case of synthesis problems we have the input signal.

chunks.Title: Introduction to Signals and Systems
chunks.Text: We do not have the system.

chunks.Title: Introduction to Signals and Systems
chunks.Text: We have the output signal and by using the information about the input signal and the

chunks.Title: Introduction to Signals and Systems
chunks.Text: output signal we need to find out the system.

chunks.Title: Introduction to Signals and Systems
chunks.Text: Compared to analysis problem this type of problems are complicated and there may or

chunks.Title: Introduction to Signals and Systems
chunks.Text: may not be the solution of this type of problem because the system may or may not exist for

chunks.Title: Introduction to Signals and Systems
chunks.Text: the given output signal.

chunks.Title: Introduction to Signals and Systems
chunks.Text: In this course we have to learn different analysis techniques and using them we will

chunks.Title: Introduction to Signals and Systems
chunks.Text: compute the response.

chunks.Title: Introduction to Signals and Systems
chunks.Text: So basically we have to deal with analysis problems and this is all for this lecture.

chunks.Title: Introduction to Signals and Systems
chunks.Text: If you have any doubt you may ask in the comment section.

text: Welcome to the first lecture in the lecture series of signals and systems. In this lecture I will introduce signals and systems. But first we will discuss the syllabus. The syllabus is broadly classified into 10 different parts. The first one is the introductional part in which we have to deal with few basic definitions and classification of signals and systems. The second part is the basic operations on signals. In this part we will perform basic operations like scaling, shifting, integration, differentiation etc. In the third part we need to learn the basic system properties like static, dynamic, causal, non-causal etc. The fourth part is the time domain analysis of continuous and discrete time systems. The 5th part is the Fourier series analysis of continuous time signals and discrete time signals. CTS stands for continuous time signals and DTS stands for discrete time signals. The 6th part is the Fourier Transform Analysis of Continuous Time Signals and Discrete Time Signals. The seventh part is the Laplace transform. The eighth part is the Z-transform or Z-transform. The ninth part is the sampling theorem. And the last part is the random signals and systems. So this is the syllabus and we will try to complete this syllabus in the coming presentations. In this lecture we will start with definition of signal. So what is a signal? A signal is a dependent variable or we can say function of one or more independent variables. So signal is a function or dependent variable which depends on one or more independent variables. And let's say x1, x2 all the way to xn are the independent variables. So function f is a signal which depends on x1 to xn because they are the independent variables. Now we will talk about difference between signal and DC value. Any quantity is said to be a signal if it is varying with independent variable. And anything which is constant is not a signal. For example, the alternating current is a signal because the current is changing with change in time. The current is alternating with change in time in case of alternating current. So it is a signal. And if we talk about the direct current, it is not a signal because the current is constant. It is not changing with change in time. So it is not a signal. We are not getting any kind of signal. We are not getting any kind of indication in case of direct current because the current is constant. So this is the difference between signal and the quantities which are not a signal. Now we will move to the next part of this lecture in which we will talk about two different types of signals. The first one is the single variable signal. And the second one is the multivariable, multivariable signal. And as the name suggests, single variable signal is the signal which only depends on one variable or we can say the function of only one variable. And the multivariable signal is the signal which depends on more than one variable. In this course, we have to deal with single variable signals only. So we will focus on single variable signal. And the example is like fx or gt. These are the examples of single variable signal. The examples of multivariable signals are f1, x1, x2 and g1, t1, t2, t3. This function depends on two variables x1 and x2 and this function here depends on three variables t1, t2 and t3 whereas function f depends on x only and this function also depends only on one variable which is time t. So this is all you need to know about the signals, the definition of signal, what is the difference between signal and DC values and the classification of the signal based on number of variables. Now I will explain what do we mean by a system. The meaningful interconnection of physical devices and components is called as system. I will repeat the definition again. The meaningful interconnection of physical devices and components is called as system. System alone cannot achieve anything. Let's represent the system by this rectangular box. This is the system and if we have a system alone it cannot achieve anything. For example let's say we want to fill the overhead tank with water using a pump. So pump is a system but alone it will not be able to complete the task. So the system which is the pump must be linked to a signal. The system must be linked to a signal and in this case signal is electricity. We need to provide the electricity to this pump so that it can pump the water to the overhead tank. After receiving the signal the system must process the signal and produce another signal which is more desirable than the input signal. So this signal here is the input signal and after receiving the input signal the system must process this input signal to produce another signal. The output of the system is another signal and we will call this signal the output signal. So this output signal is more desirable as compared to the input signal and this pump is producing the output signal which is the mechanical work. To pump this water here to this overhead tank we need mechanical work. So this signal is much desirable as compared to electricity. The electricity cannot pump this water to this tank. We need mechanical work. So the pump receives the electricity which is the input signal and after processing it produces mechanical work which is the output signal and using the mechanical work we can fill the overhead tank. I want to make one thing very clear. Electricity is not always less desirable than the mechanical work. In this scenario when we want to pump the water to the overhead tank the mechanical work is more desirable as compared to the electricity but in other cases electricity may be more desirable as compared to the mechanical work. So the input signal and the output signal purely depends on the task we want to achieve. The output signal also depends on the same variables. For example if the input signal is the function f and it depends on x1, x2 then the output signal and let's say the output signal is the function g it also depends on the same variables x1 and x2. There are two types of problems we have to deal with. The first one is the analysis problem. The second one is the synthesis problem. In case of analysis problem we have the input signal. The input signal is there. We have the system. The system is there and we have to find out the output signal. In other words we can say we have the system, we have the input signal and we need to find out the response of the system. This type of problems are most general type and there is always a solution of this type of problem. On the other hand in case of synthesis problems we have the input signal. We do not have the system. We have the output signal and by using the information about the input signal and the output signal we need to find out the system. Compared to analysis problem this type of problems are complicated and there may or may not be the solution of this type of problem because the system may or may not exist for the given output signal. In this course we have to learn different analysis techniques and using them we will compute the response. So basically we have to deal with analysis problems and this is all for this lecture.
